Description: Approximately half of a man's Roman-style sleeveless linen tunic; mainly linen with two weft-faced clavi in purple and blue wool (4cm wide); plain selvedge forming hem and neck-opening formed by internal selvedges strengthened at ends by double rows of twinning in linen; at the sides are short warp fringes (c.2 and 2.5cm long) preceded by bands of empty warp threads; self-stripes parallel to clavi and bands of empty warp; warp-undyed linen (S/c.19), weft-undyed linen (S/c.10), wool (S/c.55); traces of sewing of side seams between fringe and band of empty warps, fringes were turned in; traces of sewing across about half way down the tunic - from waist tuck (originally 2x3 cm deep); sewing of side seams in linen (S/paired); sewing at waist tuck in linen (S) and undyed wool (S/paired); original proportions of made up tunic = 118cm long (-6cm for neck) x 150cm
Curator's comments: C14 result 1570 +- 25 years BP, Calender age: 68.2%: 430-540 AD; 95.4%: 420-550 AD and dye analysis (red dye source from Rubiaceae family and indigo/woad) published in De Moor, et al. Fall 2010; found in an old cupboard box in M7
Bibliographic references: De Moor, et al. 2010 / Radiocarbon dating and dye analysis of Roman linen tunics and dalmatics with purple coloured design (35, 38, fig. 5)
